# The New Colossus

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the Emma Lazarus sonnet. For the 2017 video game, see
[Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus](/wiki/Wolfenstein_II:_The_New_Colossus
"Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus").

The New Colossus  
---  
[![New Colossus manuscript
Lazarus.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/New_Colossus_manuscript_Lazarus.jpg/220px-
New_Colossus_manuscript_Lazarus.jpg)](/wiki/File:New_Colossus_manuscript_Lazarus.jpg)
Emma Lazarus's manuscript  
Created | 1883  
Location | [Statue of Liberty](/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty"), [Liberty Island](/wiki/Liberty_Island "Liberty Island"), [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), [New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"), U.S.[1]  
Author(s) | [Emma Lazarus](/wiki/Emma_Lazarus "Emma Lazarus")  
Purpose | [Sonnet](/wiki/Sonnet "Sonnet") was engraved on a bronze plaque and mounted inside the monument in 1903  
  
"**The New Colossus** " is a [sonnet](/wiki/Sonnet "Sonnet") that American
poet [Emma Lazarus](/wiki/Emma_Lazarus "Emma Lazarus") (1849–1887) wrote in
1883 to raise money for the construction of a pedestal for the [Statue of
Liberty](/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty").[2] In 1903, the poem
was engraved on a bronze plaque and mounted inside the pedestal's lower level.

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 History of the poem
  * 2 Contents
  * 3 Influence
  * 4 References
  * 5 External links

## History of the
poem[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_New_Colossus&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History of the poem")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Statue_of_Liberty_7.jpg/170px-
Statue_of_Liberty_7.jpg)](/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty_7.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty_7.jpg "Enlarge")

The Statue of Liberty in New York City

This poem was written as a donation to an auction of art and literary works[3]
conducted by the "Art Loan Fund Exhibition in Aid of the
[Bartholdi](/wiki/Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric_Auguste_Bartholdi "Frédéric Auguste
Bartholdi") Pedestal Fund for the [Statue of Liberty](/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty
"Statue of Liberty")" to raise money for the pedestal's construction.[4]
Lazarus's contribution was solicited by fundraiser [William Maxwell
Evarts](/wiki/William_Maxwell_Evarts "William Maxwell Evarts"). Initially she
refused but writer [Constance Cary Harrison](/wiki/Constance_Cary_Harrison
"Constance Cary Harrison") convinced her that the statue would be of great
significance to immigrants sailing into the harbor.[5]

"The New Colossus" was the first entry read at the exhibit's opening on
November 2, 1883, and remained associated with the exhibit through a published
catalog until the exhibit closed after the pedestal was fully funded in August
1885,[6][7] but was forgotten and played no role at the opening of the statue
in 1886. It was, however, published in [Joseph Pulitzer](/wiki/Joseph_Pulitzer
"Joseph Pulitzer")'s _[New York World](/wiki/New_York_World "New York World")_
as well as _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_ during this time period.[8] In 1901, Lazarus's friend Georgina
Schuyler began an effort to memorialize Lazarus and her poem, which succeeded
in 1903 when a plaque bearing the text of the poem was put on the inner wall
of the pedestal of the Statue of Liberty.[4]

The line "Keep, ancient lands, your storied pomp!" is missing a comma, and
reads "Keep ancient lands, your storied pomp!" on the plaque hanging inside
the Statue of Liberty[9] since its unveiling in 1903.

The original manuscript is held by the [American Jewish Historical
Society](/wiki/American_Jewish_Historical_Society "American Jewish Historical
Society").[10]

## Contents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_New_Colossus&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Contents")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Colosse_de_Rhodes_%28Barclay%29.jpg/220px-
Colosse_de_Rhodes_%28Barclay%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Colosse_de_Rhodes_\(Barclay\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Colosse_de_Rhodes_\(Barclay\).jpg "Enlarge")

_[The Colossus of Rhodes](/wiki/The_Colossus_of_Rhodes "The Colossus of
Rhodes")_ , as depicted in an artist's impression of 1880

> Not like the brazen giant of Greek fame,  
>  With conquering limbs astride from land to land;  
>  Here at our sea-washed, sunset gates shall stand  
>  A mighty woman with a torch, whose flame  
>  Is the imprisoned lightning, and her name  
>  MOTHER OF EXILES. From her beacon-hand  
>  Glows world-wide welcome; her mild eyes command  
>  The air-bridged harbor that twin cities frame.  
>  
>  "Keep, ancient lands, your storied pomp!" cries she  
>  With silent lips. "Give me your tired, your poor,  
>  Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free,  
>  The wretched refuse of your teeming shore.  
>  Send these, the homeless, tempest-tost to me,  
>  I lift my lamp beside the golden door!"

The poem is a [Petrarchan sonnet](/wiki/Petrarchan_sonnet "Petrarchan
sonnet").

The title of the poem and the first two lines refer to the [Colossus of
Rhodes](/wiki/Colossus_of_Rhodes "Colossus of Rhodes"), which was one of the
[Seven Wonders of the Ancient World](/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World
"Seven Wonders of the Ancient World"), sometimes described as standing astride
the harbor.

The "sea-washed, sunset gates" are the mouths of the Hudson and East Rivers,
to the west of Brooklyn. The "imprisoned lightning" refers to the electric
light in the torch, then a novelty.

The "air-bridged harbor that twin cities frame" refers to [New York
Harbor](/wiki/New_York_Harbor "New York Harbor") between [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") and [Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn
"Brooklyn"), which were [consolidated into one
unit](/wiki/City_of_Greater_New_York "City of Greater New York") in 1898, 15
years after the poem was written.

The "huddled masses" are the many [immigrants](/wiki/Immigrant "Immigrant")
coming to the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") (many of
them through [Ellis Island](/wiki/Ellis_Island "Ellis Island") at the port of
New York).

## Influence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_New_Colossus&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Influence")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Emma_Lazarus_plaque.jpg/220px-
Emma_Lazarus_plaque.jpg)](/wiki/File:Emma_Lazarus_plaque.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Emma_Lazarus_plaque.jpg "Enlarge")

Bronze plaque inside the Statue of Liberty

[Paul Auster](/wiki/Paul_Auster "Paul Auster") wrote that "Bartholdi's
gigantic effigy was originally intended as a monument to the principles of
international [republicanism](/wiki/Republicanism "Republicanism"), but 'The
New Colossus' reinvented the statue's purpose, turning Liberty into a
welcoming mother, a symbol of hope to the outcasts and downtrodden of the
world."[11]

[John T. Cunningham](/wiki/John_T._Cunningham "John T. Cunningham") wrote that
"The Statue of Liberty was not conceived and sculpted as a symbol of
immigration, but it quickly became so as immigrant ships passed under the
torch and the shining face, heading toward Ellis Island. However, it was
[Lazarus's poem] that permanently stamped on Miss Liberty the role of
unofficial greeter of incoming immigrants."[12]

The poem has entered the political realm. It was quoted in [John F.
Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy")'s book _[A Nation of
Immigrants](/wiki/A_Nation_of_Immigrants "A Nation of Immigrants")_ (1958)[13]
as well as a 2010 political speech by [President Obama](/wiki/President_Obama
"President Obama") advocating immigration policy reform.[14] On August 2nd,
2017, the poem and its importance to the Statue of Liberty's symbolism and
thus the effect on American immigration policy, was debated in a White House
briefing.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Classical composer [David Ludwig](/wiki/David_Ludwig_\(composer\) "David
Ludwig \(composer\)") set the poem to music, which was performed at the
worship service of President Obama's 2013 inauguration ceremony.[15]

Author and scholar Julia Gordon-Bramer theorizes that Sylvia Plath's poem,
"Lady Lazarus," is about the Statue of Liberty and Lazarus in her book, _Fixed
Stars Govern a Life: Decoding Sylvia Plath_ , volume one (2014, Stephen F.
Austin State University Press).

Parts of the poem also appear in popular culture. The Broadway musical _[Miss
Liberty](/wiki/Miss_Liberty "Miss Liberty")_ , with music and lyrics by
[Irving Berlin](/wiki/Irving_Berlin "Irving Berlin"), an immigrant himself,
used the final stanza beginning "Give me your tired, your poor" as the basis
for a song.[16][13] It was also read in the 1941 film _[Hold Back the
Dawn](/wiki/Hold_Back_the_Dawn "Hold Back the Dawn")_ as well as being recited
by the heroine in [Alfred Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred
Hitchcock")'s wartime film _[Saboteur](/wiki/Saboteur_\(film\) "Saboteur
\(film\)")_.[13] Harpist and singer [Joanna Newsom](/wiki/Joanna_Newsom
"Joanna Newsom") indirectly references the poem in her 2015 song
"Sapokanikan," in contrast to the forbidding colossus of [Percy Bysshe
Shelley](/wiki/Percy_Bysshe_Shelley "Percy Bysshe Shelley")'s
_[Ozymandias](/wiki/Ozymandias "Ozymandias")_.[17] The poem is read aloud in
the eponymous episode,"New Colossus", in the 2016 Netflix web series _[The
OA](/wiki/The_OA "The OA")_.[18]
